title: 莊子
source: Chinese Text Project (ctext.org) - James Legge translation

passages.zh: 達生之情者，不務生之所無以為；達命之情者，不務知之所無奈何。
passages.en: He who understands the conditions of Life does not strive after what is of no use to life; and he who understands the conditions of Destiny does not strive after what is beyond the reach of knowledge.

passages.zh: 養形必先之以物，物有餘而形不養者有之矣；有生必先無離形，形不離而生亡者有之矣。
passages.en: In nourishing the body it is necessary to have beforehand the things (appropriate to its support); but there are cases where there is a superabundance of such things, and yet the body is not nourished. In order to have life it is necessary that it do not have left the body; but there are cases when the body has not been left by it, and yet the life has perished.

passages.zh: 生之來不能卻，其去不能止。
passages.en: When life comes, it cannot be declined; when it goes, it cannot be detained.

passages.zh: 悲夫！
passages.en: Alas!

passages.zh: 世之人以為養形足以存生，而養形果不足以存生，則世奚足為哉！
passages.en: The men of the world think that to nourish the body is sufficient to preserve life; and when such nourishment is not sufficient to preserve the life, what can be done in the world that will be sufficient?

passages.zh: 雖不足為而不可不為者，其為不免矣。
passages.en: Though (all that men can do) will be insufficient, yet there are things which they feel they ought to do, and they do not try to avoid doing them.

passages.zh: 夫欲免為形者，莫如棄世。
passages.en: For those who wish to avoid caring for the body, their best plan is to abandon the world.

passages.zh: 棄世則無累，無累則正平，正平則與彼更生，更生則幾矣。
passages.en: Abandoning the world, they are free from its entanglements. Free from its entanglements, their (minds) are correct and their (temperament) is equable. Thus correct and equable, they succeed in securing a renewal of life, as some have done. In securing a renewal of life, they are not far from the True (Secret of their being).

passages.zh: 事奚足棄而生奚足遺？
passages.en: But how is it sufficient to abandon worldly affairs? and how is it sufficient to forget the (business of) life?

passages.zh: 棄事則形不勞，遺生則精不虧。
passages.en: Through the renouncing of (worldly) affairs, the body has no more toil; through forgetting the (business of) life, the vital power suffers no diminution.

passages.zh: 夫形全精復，與天為一。
passages.en: When the body is completed and the vital power is restored (to its original vigour), the man is one with Heaven.

passages.zh: 天地者，萬物之父母也，合則成體，散則成始。
passages.en: Heaven and Earth are the father and mother of all things. It is by their union that the body is formed; it is by their separation that a (new) beginning is brought about.

passages.zh: 形精不虧，是謂能移；精而又精，反以相天。
passages.en: When the body and vital power suffer no diminution, we have what may be called the transference of power. From the vital force there comes another more vital, and man returns to be the assistant of Heaven.

passages.zh: 子列子問關尹曰：「至人潛行不窒，蹈火不熱，行乎萬物之上而不慄。
passages.en: My master Liezi asked Yin, (the warden) of the gate, saying, 'The perfect man walks under water without encountering any obstruction, treads on fire without being burned, and walks on high above all things without any fear.

passages.zh: 請問何以至於此？」
passages.en: Let me ask how he attains to do this?'

passages.zh: 關尹曰：「是純氣之守也，非知巧果敢之列。
passages.en: The warden Yin replied, 'It is by his keeping of the pure breath (of life); it is not to be described as an achievement of his skill or daring.

passages.zh: 居！
passages.en: Sit down, and I will explain it to you.

passages.zh: 吾語女。
凡有貌象聲色者，皆物也，物與物何以相遠？
passages.en: Whatever has form, semblance, sound, and colour is a thing; how can one thing come to be different from another?

passages.zh: 夫奚足以至乎先？
passages.en: But it is not competent for any of these things to reach to what preceded them all - they are but (form and) visibility.

passages.zh: 是色而已。
則物之造乎不形，而止乎無所化，夫得是而窮之者，物焉得而止焉！
passages.en: But (the perfect man) attains to be (as it were) without form, and beyond the capability of being transformed. Now when one attains to this and carries it out to the highest degree, how can other things come into his way to stop him?

passages.zh: 彼將處乎不淫之度，而藏乎無端之紀，遊乎萬物之所終始，壹其性，養其氣，合其德，以通乎物之所造。
passages.en: He will occupy the place assigned to him without going beyond it, and lie concealed in the clue which has no end. He will study with delight the process which gives their beginning and ending to all things. By gathering his nature into a unity, by nourishing his vital power, by concentrating his virtue, he will penetrate to the making of things.

passages.zh: 夫若是者，其天守全，其神無郤，物奚自入焉！
passages.en: In this condition, with his heavenly constitution kept entire, and with no crevice in his spirit, how can things enter (and disturb his serenity)?'

passages.zh: 夫醉者之墜車，雖疾不死。
passages.en: Take the case of a drunken man falling from his carriage - though he may suffer injury, he will not die.

passages.zh: 骨節與人同，而犯害與人異，其神全也，乘亦不知也，墜亦不知也，死生驚懼不入乎其胷中，是故遻物而不慴。
passages.en: His bones and joints are the same as those of other men, but the injury which he receives is different: his spirit is entire. He knew nothing about his getting into the carriage, and knew nothing about his falling from it. The thought of death or life, or of any alarm or affright, does not enter his breast; and therefore he encounters danger without any shrinking from it.

passages.zh: 彼得全於酒而猶若是，而況得全於天乎！
passages.en: Completely under the influence of the liquor he has drunk, it is thus with him - how much more would it be so, if he were under the influence of his Heavenly constitution!

passages.zh: 聖人藏於天，故莫之能傷也。」
passages.en: The sagely man is kept hid in his Heavenly constitution, and therefore nothing can injure him.'

passages.zh: 復讎者不折鏌、干，雖有忮心者不怨飄瓦，是以天下平均。
passages.en: A man in the pursuit of vengeance would not break the (sword) Mo-yu or Gan-jiang (which had done the deed); nor would one, however easily made wrathful, wreak his resentment on the fallen brick. In this way all under heaven there would be peace, without the disorder of assaults and fighting, without the punishments of death and slaughter: such would be the issue of the course (which I have described).

passages.zh: 故無攻戰之亂，無殺戮之刑者，由此道也。
不開人之天，而開天之天，開天者德生，開人者賊生。
passages.en: If the disposition that is of human origin be not developed, but that which is the gift of Heaven, the development of the latter will produce goodness, while that of the former would produce hurt.

passages.zh: 不厭其天，不忽於人，民幾乎以其真。
passages.en: If the latter were not wearied of, and the former not slighted, the people would be brought nearly to their True nature.'

passages.zh: 仲尼適楚，出於林中，見痀僂者承蜩，猶掇之也。
passages.en: When Zhongni was on his way to Chu, as he issued from a forest, he saw a hunchback receiving cicadas (on the point of a rod), as if he were picking them up with his hand.

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「子巧乎？
passages.en: 'You are clever!' said he to the man.

passages.zh: 有道邪？」
passages.en: 'Is there any method in it?'

passages.zh: 曰：「我有道也。
passages.en: The hunchback replied, 'There is.

passages.zh: 五六月累丸，二而不墜，則失者錙銖；累三而不墜，則失者十一；累五而不墜，猶掇之也。
passages.en: For five or six months, I practised with two pellets, till they never fell down, and then I only failed with a small fraction of the cicadas (which I tried to catch). Having succeeded in the same way with three (pellets), I missed only one cicada in ten. Having succeeded with five, I caught the cicadas as if I were gathering them.

passages.zh: 吾處身也若厥株拘，吾執臂也若槁木之枝，雖天地之大，萬物之多，而唯蜩翼之知。
passages.en: My body is to me no more than the stump of a broken trunk, and my shoulder no more than the branch of a rotten tree. Great as heaven and earth are, and multitudinous as things are, I take no notice of them, but only of the wings of my cicadas.

passages.zh: 吾不反不側，不以萬物易蜩之翼，何為而不得！」
passages.en: Neither turning nor inclining to one side. I would not for them all exchange the wings of my cicadas - how should I not succeed in taking them?'

passages.zh: 孔子顧謂弟子曰：「用志不分，乃凝於神，其痀僂丈人之謂乎！」
passages.en: Confucius looked round, and said to his disciples, '"Where the will is not diverted from its object, the spirit is concentrated" - this might have been spoken of this hunchback gentleman.'

passages.zh: 顏淵問仲尼曰：「吾嘗濟乎觴深之淵，津人操舟若神。
passages.en: Yan Yuan asked Zhongni, saying, 'When I was crossing the gulf of Shang-shen, the ferryman handled the boat like a spirit.

passages.zh: 吾問焉，曰：『操舟可學邪？』
passages.en: I asked him whether such management of a boat could be learned.

passages.zh: 曰：『可。
passages.en: He replied, "It may.

passages.zh: 善游者數能。
passages.en: Good swimmers can learn it quickly.

passages.zh: 若乃夫沒人，則未嘗見舟而便操之也。』
passages.en: But as for divers, without having seen a boat, they can manage it at once."

passages.zh: 吾問焉而不吾告，敢問何謂也？」
passages.en: He did not directly tell me what I asked - I venture to ask you what he meant.'

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「善游者數能，忘水也。
passages.en: Zhongni replied, 'Good swimmers acquire the ability quickly - they forget the water (and its dangers).

passages.zh: 若乃夫沒人之未嘗見舟而便操之也，彼視淵若陵，視舟之覆猶其車卻也。
passages.en: As to those who are able to dive, and without having seen a boat are able to manage it at once, they look on the watery gulf as if it were a hill-side, and the upsetting of a boat as the going back of a carriage.

passages.zh: 覆卻萬方陳乎前而不得入其舍，惡往而不暇！
passages.en: Such upsettings and goings back have occurred before them multitudes of times, and have not seriously affected their minds. Wherever they go, they feel at ease on their occurrence.

passages.zh: 以瓦注者巧，以鉤注者憚，以黃金注者殙。
passages.en: He who is contending for a piece of earthenware puts forth all his skill. If the prize be a buckle of brass, he shoots timorously; if it be for an article of gold, he shoots as if he were blind.

passages.zh: 其巧一也，而有所矜，則重外也。
passages.en: The skill of the archer is the same in all the cases; but (in the two latter cases) he is under the influence of solicitude, and looks on the external prize as most important.

passages.zh: 凡外重者內拙。」
passages.en: All who attach importance to what is external show stupidity in themselves.'

passages.zh: 田開之見周威公。
passages.en: Tian Kai-zhi was having an interview with duke Wei Of Zhou.

passages.zh: 威公曰：「吾聞祝腎學生。
passages.en: The duke said to him, 'I have heard that (your master) Zhu Shen has studied the subject of Life.

passages.zh: 吾子與祝腎游，亦何聞焉？」
passages.en: What have you, good Sir, heard from him about it in your intercourse with him?'

passages.zh: 田開之曰：「開之操拔篲以倚門庭，亦何聞於夫子！」
passages.en: Tian Kai-zhi replied, 'In my waiting on him in the courtyard with my broom, what should I have heard from my master?'

passages.zh: 威公曰：「田子無讓！
passages.en: Duke Wei said, 'Do not put the question off, Mr. Tian; I wish to hear what you have to say.'

passages.zh: 寡人願聞之。」
開之曰：「聞之夫子曰：『善養生者，若牧羊然，視其後者而鞭之。』」
passages.en: Kai-zhi then replied, 'I have heard my master say that they who skilfully nourish their life are like shepherds, who whip up the sheep that they see lagging behind.'

passages.zh: 威公曰：「何謂也？」
passages.en: 'What did he mean?' asked the duke.

passages.zh: 田開之曰：「魯有單豹者，巖居而水飲，不與民共利，行年七十而猶有嬰兒之色，不幸遇餓虎，餓虎殺而食之。
passages.en: The reply was, 'In Lu there was a Shan Bao, who lived among the rocks, and drank only water. He would not share with the people in their toils and the benefits springing from them; and though he was now in his seventieth year, he had still the complexion of a child. Unfortunately he encountered a hungry tiger, which killed and ate him.

passages.zh: 有張毅者，高門、懸薄，無不走也，行年四十而有內熱之病以死。
passages.en: There was also a Zhang Yi, who hung up a screen at his lofty door, and to whom all the people hurried (to pay their respects). In his fortieth year, he fell ill of a fever and died.

passages.zh: 豹養其內而虎食其外，毅養其外而病攻其內，此二子者，皆不鞭其後者也。」
passages.en: (Of these two men), Bao nourished his inner man, and a tiger ate his outer; while Yi nourished his outer man, and disease attacked his inner. Both of them neglected whipping up their lagging sheep.'

passages.zh: 仲尼曰：「無入而藏，無出而陽，柴立其中央。
passages.en: Zhongni said, 'A man should not retire and hide himself; he should not push forward and display himself; he should be like the decayed tree which stands in the centre of the ground.

passages.zh: 三者若得，其名必極。
passages.en: Where these three conditions are fulfilled, the name will reach its greatest height.

passages.zh: 夫畏塗者，十殺一人，則父子兄弟相戒也，必盛卒徒而後敢出焉，不亦知乎！
passages.en: When people fear the dangers of a path, if one man in ten be killed, then fathers and sons, elder brothers and younger, warn one another that they must not go out on a journey without a large number of retainers - and is it not a mark of wisdom to do so?

passages.zh: 人之所取畏者，衽席之上，飲食之間，而不知為之戒者，過也。」
passages.en: But there are dangers which men incur on the mats of their beds, and in eating and drinking; and when no warning is given against them - is it not a mark of error?'

passages.zh: 祝宗人玄端以臨牢筴，說彘曰：「汝奚惡死？
passages.en: The officer of Prayer in his dark and squarecut robes goes to the pig-pen, and thus counsels the pigs, 'Why should you shrink from dying?

passages.zh: 吾將三月豢汝，十日戒，三日齊，藉白茅，加汝肩尻乎彫俎之上，則汝為之乎？」
passages.en: I will for three months feed you on grain. Then for ten days I will fast, and keep vigil for three days, after which I will put down the mats of white grass, and lay your shoulders and rumps on the carved stand; will not this suit you?'

passages.zh: 為彘謀曰：「不如食以糠糟，而錯之牢筴之中。」
passages.en: If he had spoken from the standpoint of the pigs, he would have said, 'The better plan will be to feed us with our bran and chaff, and leave us in our pen.'

passages.zh: 自為謀，則苟生有軒冕之尊，死得於腞、楯之上，聚僂之中，則為之。
passages.en: When consulting for himself, he preferred to enjoy, while he lived, his carriage and cap of office, and after death to be borne to the grave on the ornamented carriage, with the canopy over his coffin.

passages.zh: 為彘謀則去之，自為謀則取之，所異彘者何也？
passages.en: Consulting for the pigs, he did not think of these things, but for himself he would have chosen them. Why did he think so differently (for himself and) for the pigs?

passages.zh: 桓公田於澤，管仲御，見鬼焉。
passages.en: (Once), when duke Huan was hunting by a marsh, with Guan Zhong driving the carriage, he saw a ghost.

passages.zh: 公撫管仲之手曰：「仲父何見？」
passages.en: Laying his hand on that of Guan Zhong, he said to him, 'Do you see anything, Father Zhong?'

passages.zh: 對曰：「臣無所見。」
passages.en: 'Your servant sees nothing,' was the reply.

passages.zh: 公反，誒詒為病，數日不出。
passages.en: The duke then returned, talking incoherently and becoming ill, so that for several days he did not go out.

passages.zh: 齊士有皇子告敖者曰：「公則自傷，鬼惡能傷公！
passages.en: Among the officers of Qi there was a Huang-zi Gao-ao, who said to the duke, 'Your Grace is injuring yourself; how could a ghost injure you?

passages.zh: 夫忿滀之氣，散而不反，則為不足；上而不下，則使人善怒；下而不上，則使人善忘；不上不下，中身當心，則為病。」
passages.en: When a paroxysm of irritation is dispersed, and the breath does not return (to the body), what remains in the body is not sufficient for its wants. When it ascends and does not descend, the patient becomes accessible to gusts of anger. When it descends and does not ascend, he loses his memory of things. When it neither ascends nor descends, but remains about the heart in the centre of the body, it makes him ill.'

passages.zh: 桓公曰：「然則有鬼乎？」
passages.en: The duke said, 'Yes, but are there ghostly sprites?'

passages.zh: 曰：「有。
passages.en: The officer replied, 'There are.

passages.zh: 沈有履，灶有髻。
passages.en: About mountain tarns there is the lu; about furnaces, the Jie.

passages.zh: 戶內之煩壤，雷霆處之；東北方之下者，倍阿、鮭蠪躍之；西北方之下者，則泆陽處之。
passages.en: About the dust-heaps inside the door, the Lei-ting. In low-lying places in the north-east, the Bei-a and Wa-long leap about, and in similar places in the north-west there dwells the Yi-yang.

passages.zh: 水有罔象，丘有峷，山有夔，野有彷徨，澤有委蛇。」
passages.en: About rivers there is the Wang-xiang; about mounds, the Shen; about hills, the Kui; about wilds, the Fang-huang; about marshes, the Wei-tuo.'

passages.zh: 公曰：「請問委蛇之狀何如？」
passages.en: 'Let me ask what is the Wei-tuo like?' asked the duke.

passages.zh: 皇子曰：「委蛇，其大如轂，其長如轅，紫衣而朱冠。
passages.en: Huang-zi said, 'It is the size of the nave of a chariot wheel, and the length of the shaft. It wears a purple robe and a red cap.

passages.zh: 其為物也惡，聞雷車之聲，則捧其首而立。
passages.en: It dislikes the rumbling noise of chariot wheels, and, when it hears it, it puts both its hands to its head and stands up.

passages.zh: 見之者殆乎霸。」
passages.en: He who sees it is likely to become the leader of all the other princes.'

passages.zh: 桓公囅然而笑曰：「此寡人之所見者也。」
passages.en: Duke Huan burst out laughing and said, 'This was what I saw.'

passages.zh: 於是正衣冠與之坐，不終日而不知病之去也。
passages.en: On this he put his robes and cap to rights, and made Huang-zi sit with him. Before the day was done, his illness was quite gone, he knew not how.

passages.zh: 紀渻子為王養鬥雞。
passages.en: Ji Xing-zi was rearing a fighting-cock for the king.

passages.zh: 十日而問：「雞已乎？」
passages.en: Being asked after ten days if the bird were ready, he said, 'Not yet; he is still vain and quarrelsome, and relies on his own vigour.'

passages.zh: 曰：「未也。
方虛憍而恃氣。」
十日又問。
passages.en: Being asked the same after other ten days, he said, 'Not yet; he still responds to the crow and the appearance of another bird.'

passages.zh: 曰：「未也。
猶應嚮景。」
十日又問。
passages.en: After ten days more, he replied, 'Not yet. He still looks angrily, and is full of spirit.'

passages.zh: 曰：「未也。
猶疾視而盛氣。」
十日又問。
passages.en: When a fourth ten days had passed, he replied to the question, 'Nearly so.

passages.zh: 曰：「幾矣。
雞雖有鳴者，已無變矣，望之似木雞矣，其德全矣，異雞無敢應者，反走矣。」
passages.en: Though another cock crows, it makes no change in him. To look at him, you would say he was a cock of wood. His quality is complete. No other cock will dare to meet him, but will run from him.'

passages.zh: 孔子觀於呂梁，縣水三十仞，流沫四十里，黿鼉魚龞之所不能游也。
passages.en: Confucius was looking at the cataract near the gorge of Lu, which fell a height of 240 cubits, and the spray of which floated a distance of forty li, (producing a turbulence) in which no tortoise, gavial, fish, or turtle could play.

passages.zh: 見一丈夫游之，以為有苦而欲死也，使弟子並流而拯之。
passages.en: He saw, however, an old man swimming about in it, as if he had sustained some great calamity, and wished to end his life. Confucius made his disciples hasten along the stream to rescue the man.

passages.zh: 數百步而出，被髮行歌而游於塘下。
passages.en: And by the time they had gone several hundred paces, he was walking along singing, with his hair dishevelled, and enjoying himself at the foot of the embankment.

passages.zh: 孔子從而問焉，曰：「吾以子為鬼，察子則人也。
passages.en: Confucius followed and asked him, saying, 'I thought you were a sprite; but, when I look closely at you, I see that you are a man.

passages.zh: 請問蹈水有道乎？」
passages.en: Let me ask if you have any particular way of treading the water.'

passages.zh: 曰：「亡，吾無道。
passages.en: The man said, 'No, I have no particular way.

passages.zh: 吾始乎故，長乎性，成乎命。
passages.en: I began (to learn the art) at the very earliest time; as I grew up, it became my nature to practise it; and my success in it now is as sure as fate.

passages.zh: 與齊俱入，與汩偕出，從水之道而不為私焉。
passages.en: I enter and go down with the water in the very centre of its whirl, and come up again with it when it whirls the other way. I follow the way of the water, and do nothing contrary to it of myself - this is how I tread it.'

passages.zh: 此吾所以蹈之也。」
孔子曰：「何謂始乎故，長乎性，成乎命？」
passages.en: Confucius said, 'What do you mean by saying that you began to learn the art at the very earliest time; that as you grew up, it became your nature to practise it, and that your success in it now is as sure as fate?'

passages.zh: 曰：「吾生於陵而安於陵，故也；長於水而安於水，性也；不知吾所以然而然，命也。」
passages.en: The man replied, 'I was born among these hills and lived contented among them - that was why I say that I have trod this water from my earliest time. I grew up by it, and have been happy treading it - that is why I said that to tread it had become natural to me. I know not how I do it, and yet I do it - that is why I say that my success is as sure as fate.'

passages.zh: 梓慶削木為鐻，鐻成，見者驚猶鬼神。
passages.en: Qing, the Worker in Rottlera wood, carved a bell-stand, and when it was completed, all who saw it were astonished as if it were the work of spirits.

passages.zh: 魯侯見而問焉，曰：「子何術以為焉？」
passages.en: The marquis of Lu went to see it, and asked by what art he had succeeded in producing it.

passages.zh: 對曰：「臣工人，何術之有！
passages.en: 'Your subject is but a mechanic,' was the reply; 'what art should I be possessed of?

passages.zh: 雖然，有一焉。
passages.en: Nevertheless, there is one thing (which I will mention).

passages.zh: 臣將為鐻，未嘗敢以耗氣也，必齊以靜心。
passages.en: When your servant had undertaken to make the bell-stand, I did not venture to waste any of my power, and felt it necessary to fast in order to compose my mind.

passages.zh: 齊三日，而不敢懷慶賞爵祿；齊五日，不敢懷非譽巧拙；齊七日，輒然忘吾有四枝形體也。
passages.en: After fasting for three days, I did not presume to think of any congratulation, reward, rank, or emolument (which I might obtain by the execution of my task); after fasting five days, I did not presume to think of the condemnation or commendation (which it would produce), or of the skill or want of skill (which it might display). At the end of the seven days, I had forgotten all about myself - my four limbs and my whole person.

passages.zh: 當是時也，無公朝，其巧專而外骨消；然後入山林，觀天性；形軀至矣，然後成見鐻，然後加手焉；不然則已。
passages.en: By this time the thought of your Grace's court (for which I was to make the thing) had passed away; everything that could divert my mind from exclusive devotion to the exercise of my skill had disappeared. Then I went into the forest, and looked at the natural forms of the trees. When I saw one of a perfect form, then the figure of the bell-stand rose up to my view, and I applied my hand to the work. Had I not met with such a tree, I must have abandoned the object.

passages.zh: 則以天合天，器之所以疑神者，其是與？」
passages.en: But my Heaven-given faculty and the Heaven-given qualities of the wood were concentrated on it. So it was that my spirit was thus engaged in the production of the bell-stand.'

passages.zh: 東野稷以御見莊公，進退中繩，左右旋中規。
passages.en: Dong-ye Ji was introduced to duke Zhuang to exhibit his driving. His horses went forwards and backwards with the straightness of a line, and wheeled to the right and the left with the exactness of a circle.

passages.zh: 莊公以為文弗過也，使之鉤百而反。
passages.en: The duke thought that the lines and circles could not be surpassed if they were woven with silken strings, and told him to make a hundred circuits on the same lines.

passages.zh: 顏闔遇之，入見曰：「稷之馬將敗。」
passages.en: On the road Yan He met the equipage, and on entering (the palace), and seeing the duke, he said, 'Ji's horses will break down,' but the duke was silent, and gave him no reply.

passages.zh: 公密而不應。
少焉，果敗而反。
passages.en: After a little the horses did come back, having broken down.

passages.zh: 公曰：「子何以知之？」
passages.en: The duke then said, 'How did you know that it would be so?'

passages.zh: 曰：「其馬力竭矣，而猶求焉，故曰敗。」
passages.en: Yan He said, 'The horses were exhausted, and he was still urging them on. It was this which made me say that they would break down.'

passages.zh: 工倕旋而蓋規矩，指與物化，而不以心稽，故其靈臺一而不桎。
passages.en: The artisan Chui made things round (and square) more exactly than if he had used the circle and square. The operation of his fingers on (the forms of) things was like the transformations of them (in nature), and required no application of his mind; and so his Intelligence was entire and encountered no resistance.

passages.zh: 忘足，履之適也；忘要，帶之適也；知忘是非，心之適也；不內變，不外從，事會之適也。
passages.en: To be unthought of by the foot that wears it is the fitness of a shoe; to be unthought of by the waist is the fitness of a girdle. When one's wisdom does not think of the right or the wrong (of a question under discussion), that shows the suitability of the mind (for the question); when one is conscious of no inward change, or outward attraction, that shows the mastery of affairs.

passages.zh: 始乎適而未嘗不適者，忘適之適也。
passages.en: He who perceives at once the fitness, and never loses the sense of it, has the fitness that forgets all about what is fitting.

passages.zh: 有孫休者，踵門而詫子扁慶子曰：「休居鄉不見謂不修，臨難不見謂不勇，然而田原不遇歲，事君不遇世，賓於鄉里，逐於州部，則胡罪乎天哉？
passages.en: There was a Sun Xiu who went to the door of Zi-bian Qing-zi, and said to him in a strange perturbed way, 'When I lived in my village, no one took notice of me, but all said that I did not cultivate (my fields); in a time of trouble and attack, no one took notice of me, but all said that I had no courage. But that I did not cultivate my fields, was really because I never met with a good year; and that I did not do service for our ruler, was because I did not meet with the suitable opportunity to do so. I have been sent about my business by the villagers, and am driven away by the registrars of the district - what is my crime? 0 Heaven! how is it that I have met with such a fate?'

passages.zh: 休惡遇此命也？」
扁子曰：「子獨不聞夫至人之自行邪？
passages.en: Bian-zi said to him, 'Have you not heard how the perfect man deals with himself?

passages.zh: 忘其肝膽，遺其耳目，芒然彷徨乎塵垢之外，逍遙乎無事之業，是謂『為而不恃，長而不宰』。
passages.en: He forgets that he has a liver and gall. He takes no thought of his ears and eyes. He seems lost and aimless beyond the dust and dirt of the world, and enjoys himself at ease in occupations untroubled by the affairs of business. He may be described as acting and yet not relying on what he does, as being superior and yet not using his superiority to exercise any control.

passages.zh: 今汝飾知以驚愚，修身以明汙，昭昭乎若揭日月而行也。
passages.en: But now you would make a display of your wisdom to astonish the ignorant; you would cultivate your person to make the inferiority of others more apparent; you seek to shine as if you were carrying the sun and moon in your hands.

passages.zh: 汝得全而形軀，具而九竅，無中道夭於聾盲跛蹇而比於人數，亦幸矣，又何暇乎天之怨哉！
passages.en: That you are complete in your bodily frame, and possess all its nine openings; that you have not met with any calamity in the middle of your course, such as deafness, blindness, or lameness, and can still take your place as a man among other men - in all this you are fortunate. What leisure have you to murmur against Heaven?

passages.zh: 子往矣！」
passages.en: Go away, Sir.'

passages.zh: 孫子出。
passages.en: Sun-zi on this went out, and Bian-zi went inside.

passages.zh: 扁子入坐，有間，仰天而歎。
passages.en: Having sitten down, after a little time he looked up to heaven, and sighed.

passages.zh: 弟子問曰：「先生何為歎乎？」
passages.en: His disciples asked him why he sighed.

passages.zh: 扁子曰：「向者休來，吾告之以至人之德，吾恐其驚而遂至於惑也。」
passages.en: He said to them, 'Xiu came to me a little while ago, and I told him the characteristics of the perfect man. I am afraid he will be frightened, and get into a state of perplexity.'

passages.zh: 弟子曰：「不然。
passages.en: His disciples said, 'Not so.

passages.zh: 孫子之所言是邪，先生之所言非邪，非固不能惑是。
passages.en: If what he said was right, and what you said was wrong, the wrong will certainly not be able to perplex the right.

passages.zh: 孫子所言非邪，先生所言是邪，彼固惑而來矣，又奚罪焉？」
passages.en: If what he said was wrong, and what you said was right, it was just because he was perplexed that he came to you. What was your fault in dealing with him as you did?'

passages.zh: 扁子曰：「不然。
passages.en: Bian-zi said, 'Not so.

passages.zh: 昔者有鳥止於魯郊，魯君說之，為具太牢以饗之，奏九韶以樂之，鳥乃始憂悲眩視，不敢飲食。
passages.en: Formerly a bird came, and took up its seat in the suburbs of Lu. The ruler of Lu was pleased with it, and provided an ox, a sheep, and a pig to feast it, causing also the Jiu-shao to be performed to delight it. But the bird began to be sad, looked dazed, and did not venture to eat or drink.

passages.zh: 此之謂以己養養鳥也。
passages.en: This was what is called "Nourishing a bird, as you would nourish yourself."

passages.zh: 若夫以鳥養養鳥者，宜棲之深林，浮之江湖，食之以委蛇，則平陸而已矣。
passages.en: He who would nourish a bird as a bird should be nourished should let it perch in a deep forest, or let it float on a river or lake, or let it find its food naturally and undisturbed on the level dry ground.

passages.zh: 今休，款啟寡聞之民也，吾告以至人之德，譬之若載鼷以車馬，樂鴳以鐘鼓也。
passages.en: Now Xiu (came to me), a man of slender intelligence, and slight information, and I told him of the characteristics of the perfect man, it was like using a carriage and horses to convey a mouse, or trying to delight a quail with the music of bells and drums - could the creatures help being frightened?'

passages.zh: 彼又奚能無驚乎哉？」
